Use Case Name: Thesaurus Indexing and Validation in Legal Editorial Workflows
RAG Status: Green – as per plan or better
Use Case Description: In the legal editorial domain two critical activities — thesaurus validation and thesaurus indexing — are essential for ensuring accurate classification and discoverability of legal documents. These processes traditionally require manual review of legal acts and the assignment of appropriate thesaurus terms based on legal taxonomy and editorial standards. Manual thesaurus indexing is time-consuming, prone to inconsistencies, and difficult to scale, especially when dealing with legacy documents or large volumes of new legislation.
Outcomes/Deliverables:
Tools Used: Copilot (for in-line suggestions), Open Arena (for batch processing via Ask Your Document), and internal spreadsheets for tracking.
Trigger Point: After the legal act is uploaded to GCMS.
Prompt Example: “List the main thesaurus terms applicable to this legal act.”
Output: A structured list of suggested terms, which are then reviewed and confirmed by the editorial team.
AI Application:
- Extract key legal concepts from the text of legislative acts.
- Suggest relevant thesaurus terms based on semantic understanding.
- Automate the comparison between existing thesaurus classifications and AI-suggested ones (validation).
- Highlight gaps or inconsistencies in thesaurus coverage for legacy documents.
Expected Outcomes:
- Efficiency Gains: Reduction in time spent per document indexed (e.g., from 15–20 minutes to under 5 minutes).
- Consistency: More uniform application of thesaurus terms across the database.
Challenges & Considerations:
- Accuracy: AI suggestions must be reviewed by legal editors to ensure compliance with editorial standards.
- Data Limitations: Large documents may require segmentation before processing in Open Arena.
- Training: Editors need guidance on prompt engineering and validation workflows.
Planned Status Q4 2025: Enable same-day batch processing of all captured documents using a single prompt execution (dependency development)

Use Case Name: AI in Legislative Updating – Legal Editorial Context
RAG Status: Red – stopped/postponed > 3 months
Use Case Description: Legislative updating is a core function in legal publishing and compliance workflows. It involves interpreting and incorporating amendments, revocations, and consolidations into existing legal texts, ensuring that the legal database reflects the current and enforceable version of the law. This process requires strict adherence to legal accuracy, editorial standards, and traceability of normative changes.
Outcomes/Deliverables:
Challenges
- Manual identification of amended acts is time-intensive and error-prone, especially given the complexity and growing volume of normative acts.
- Drafting legally sound editorial notes and relationship annotations demands specialized legal knowledge.
- Ensuring consistency in the application of legal effects (e.g., retroactivity, future effectiveness) across jurisdictions and document types is complex.
- High volume of legislative acts, especially in federative or multilingual systems, limits scalability.

AI-Driven Solution:
Large Language Models (LLMs) such as Copilot and Gemini are integrated into the editorial workflow to:
- Conduct an initial screening and classification of the selected legal acts based on editorial criteria for legislative updating
- Analyze the full text of amending acts and identify affected acts with legal precision.
- Suggest legal relationships (e.g., “revokes,” “amends,” “adds paragraph”) based on recognized legislative patterns.
- Generate editorial and relationship notes in compliance with internal legal editorial guidelines.
- Validate consistency between publication dates, effective dates, and legal effects.
- Classify the nature of the amendment (e.g., partial repeal, full substitution, consolidation).

Workflow Integration
- AI is triggered after the upload of the legal act into the GCMS (legal content management system).
- Prompts are executed in batch mode for all acts captured on the same day, ensuring same-day processing and editorial alignment.

Expected Legal Outcomes
- Reduced processing time per act, enabling faster publication of updated legal texts.
- Improved consistency and traceability in the application of legal relationships and editorial notes.
- Enhanced compliance with legal editorial standards and jurisdictional requirements.
- Scalability to handle high volumes of legislative changes, including legacy acts.

Success Metrics
- Time saved per legislative update.
- Accuracy and acceptance rate of AI-generated legal relationships and notes.
- Volume of acts processed daily.
- Reduction in post-publication corrections or legal inconsistencies.
Planned Status Q3 2025:
Map editorial workflows for legislative updates.
Define and test prompts for identifying amended provisions and suggesting legal relationships.
Train editorial/legal teams on prompt usage and validation of AI outputs.
Select pilot sample (e.g., 100 acts) for controlled testing and benchmarking.
Document editorial standards for AI-generated notes and relationships.
Planned Status Q4 2025:
Expand AI usage to all new acts requiring updates in GCMS.
Compare AI vs. manual outputs to refine accuracy and consistency.
Track performance metrics: time per act, acceptance rate, error rate.
Incorporate legal edge cases (e.g., retroactive effects, partial revocations).
Conduct legal/editorial review cycles to validate AI-driven updates.
Evaluate impact: productivity, legal consistency, editorial quality.
Publish internal guidelines for AI use in legislative workflows.
